parks.description: The Bluestone River and the rugged and ancient gorge it has carved is a richly diverse and scenic area of the southern Appalachians. Bluestone National Scenic River is preserved as a living landscape that provides an unspoiled experience for visitors and a haven for a variety of plants and animals. The park protects a 10.5-mile section of the Bluestone River in southern West Virginia.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for the park. Pipestem Resort State Park charges a small fee to ride the tram to and from the bottom at the entrance in Pipestem.
entranceFees.title: Entrance

parks.directionsInfo: Bluestone National Scenic River is most easily accessed via Bluestone State Park and Pipestem Resort State Park. A narrow, graveled park road provides access to the Bluestone Turnpike Trail at the former Lilly town site at the confluence of the Little Bluestone River. To reach these parks from I-64, take exit 139, then south on Rt. 20. From I-77 take exit 14 to Rt.20 north. Either direction, Bluestone State Park is 15 miles and Pipestem is 22 miles.

operatingHours.description: The park is accessible year-round at two entrance points, Bluestone State Park and the former Lilly townsite, and seasonally at Pipestem Resort State Park. The park is open 24 hours a day.
operatingHours.name: Bluestone National Scenic River

images.title: The Turnpike Trail
images.caption: The ten mile Turnpike Trail parallels the Bluestone, connecting Pipestem Resort State Park and Bluestone State Park.

images.title: Leading a hike
images.caption: Ranger Richard leads a guided walk on the Turnpike Trail

images.title: Enjoying the day
images.caption: A young hiker makes his own connection with Bluestone National Scenic River.

images.title: Bluestone River
images.caption: Bluestone National Scenic River offers a quiet getaway.

images.title: Bluestone Turnpike Trail
images.altText: Ranger giving information to park visitor
images.caption: NPS Ranger Richard Altaire provides an overview of the park map to a visitor to the Bluestone NSR.

parks.weatherInfo: Summer: Temperatures range from low to mid 60's at night to middle to upper 80's during the daytime hours. Winter: Temperatures average from the mid 20's to the mid 40's. Snowfall amount varies, but averages 5" per month Dec. - March. Spring and Fall: temperatures and rainfall variable. Peak fall foliage is usually mid-October.
parks.name: Bluestone

parks.description: Castle Mountains represents some of the most unique elements of the Mojave Desert. Nestled between the Nevada state line and Mojave National Preserve, the nearly 21,000 acres of Castle Mountains boasts Joshua tree forests, unbroken natural landscapes, rare desert grasslands, and rich human history. This intriguing area provides serenity and solitude from nearby metropolitan areas.

entranceFees.description: There are no fees to enter Castle Mountains National Monument.
entranceFees.title: Castle Mountains Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description: Castle Mountains is a fee free area.
entrancePasses.title: Castle Mountains Pass

parks.directionsInfo: You can approach Castle Mountains from Walking Box Ranch Road off of Nevada State Rd 164 (Nipton Road) or from several unnamed dirt roads off of Lanfair Road in Mojave National Preserve.

operatingHours.description: Castle Mountains National Monument is open year-round. There are no facilities in the Monument. Visitor Centers in neighboring Mojave National Preserve provide information and orientation.
operatingHours.name: Castle Mountains

images.title: Red Rocks Outcropping
images.altText: Red rocks frame a stand of Joshua trees and sage brush.
images.caption: Red rocks frame a stand of Joshua trees and sage brush in the desert floor..

images.title: View of Castle Peaks
images.altText: Foreground is desert greenery. The isolated spires of the Castle Peaks rise up in the background
images.caption: From Walking Box Ranch road, visitors to Castle Mountains can enjoy the stunning view of the Castle Peaks, which are located in surrounding Mojave National Preserve lands.

parks.weatherInfo: Weather at Castle Mountains changes with the seasons. Freezing temperatures are expected in winter, with occasional snow. Spring brings mild warm days and cooler nights. With enough rain, wildflowers can carpet the area, making for spectacular displays. Summer months are much hotter, with temperatures nearing 100 degrees Fahrenheit. Strong monsoonal storms in late summer may cause flash-flooding in low-lying areas and can create hazardous road conditions. Fall is a cooler respite after the heat of summer.
parks.name: Castle Mountains
